dataset.title: NCCN Fish Assemblages Monitoring Data Package, 1994-2011

creator.organizationName: North Coast and Cascades Network: National Park Service Inventory and Monitoring Division
National Park Service: Olympic National Park

associatedParty.organizationName: National Park Service: Olympic National Park

abstract.para: This data package contains North Coast and Cascades Network (NCCN) Inventory and Monitoring Program fish assemblages tabular data collected during 1994-2011 in Olympic National Park (OLYM).
The protocol, publications, and all other associated links can be found in the project reference at: NCCN Monitoring Fish Assemblages

Olympic National Park is the only national park in the lower 48 states that contains significant numbers of wild Pacific salmonids, with at least 70 populations in park rivers. These rivers represent some of the largest tracts of contiguous, undisturbed habitat throughout the range of several key fish species of the Pacific Northwest. These watersheds are of high regional importance as freshwater habitat sanctuaries for native fish, where habitat conditions are characterized as having little to no disturbance from development, channelization, impervious surfaces, roads, diversions, or hydroelectric projects. Salmonids are critical to ecosystem function by linking freshwater, marine, and terrestrial ecosystems. Pacific salmonids provide food for over 130 species of aquatic and terrestrial wildlife species and they contribute significant amounts of marine-derived nutrients to freshwater systems through spawned salmon carcasses. Fishery resources are of high ecological and cultural importance in Pacific Northwest National Parks, and significantly contribute to economically important recreational, commercial, and tribal fisheries.

Olympic National Park rivers contain federally threatened fish populations (e.g. bull trout, Salvelinus confluentus) and non-commercial fish species such as mountain whitefish (Prosopium williamsoni). Cutthroat trout (Oncorhynchus clarkii) and summer steelhead (Oncorhynchus mykiss) also are important species targeted by recreational anglers. Prior to the inception of this monitoring project there were no existing monitoring programs for non-commercial (e.g., Pacific salmonids) fish species in Olympic Peninsula rivers.

In this project, fish communities were monitored via repeated intensive snorkel surveys within approximately five kilometer reference sites from May to December across eight park rivers and five wadeable streams. Specific monitoring objectives of this protocol are to determine seasonal and annual trends in: (1) fish species composition, (2) timing of migration of adult fish, (3) relative abundance, (4) age and size structure, and (5) extent of non-native and hatchery fish. To detect seasonal and annual trends in fish assemblages in reference sites, we relied on repeated and consistent annual sampling at each monitoring site. The general rationale for the repeated sampling of reference sites, about 10 surveys per river per year, is to ensure that we account for the high interannual variability in fish movements and abundances in rivers.

keywordSet.keyword: Biological Integrity | Focal Species or Communities | Fishes

contact.organizationName: National Park Service: North Coast and Cascades Network

description.para: The protocol narrative describes the background, rationale, sampling design, field methods, analytical methods, data management, reporting, personnel requirements, and operational requirements for fish assemblages monitoring in OLYM. Please refer to https://irma.nps.gov/DataStore/Reference/Profile/660876 for the protocol narrative.

Survey Design The seasonal movements, assemblage structure, and relative abundances of fish species were determined by intensive, weekly snorkel counts in reference sites of each river. The objective of repeated snorkel surveys in relatively long sample sites (2.6 to 5.7 km) was to examine seasonal and annual changes in abundances of each of the primary species. The general rationale for intensive sampling (e.g., up to 10 surveys per river per year) of reference sites was to account for the high seasonal variability in fish movements and abundances in rivers. To detect seasonal and annual trends in fish communities in reference sites, we relied on repeated (e.g., multiple surveys) and consistent annual sampling using the same methods at each monitoring location.

Fish communities were monitored in reference and supplemental sites located immediately upstream of the park boundary. Reference sites were comprised of main-stem and side-channel habitats with multiple types of habitat units (e.g., pools, riffles, glides) throughout each reference site. Locating reference sites at the park boundary has the advantage of reflecting the integrated conditions of the watershed. These river reference sites were generally characterized as unconstrained, productive floodplains that are used by numerous fish species when compared to remote reaches of upper watersheds that are largely confined, and where physical barriers and waterfalls prevent upstream movements of migratory fish. Supplemental sites were non-permanent reaches surveyed opportunistically.

Survey Methods Two experienced divers, one on each side of the river, proceeded downstream counting each species of fish greater than 15 cm in fork length. When fish were observed in large aggregations, divers commonly made two passes in their respective lanes and averaged the counts. Because of the difficulty in distinguishing between cutthroat trout and rainbow trout underwater, counts of these two species were combined as cutthroat/rainbow trout. Seasonal and annual trends of proportions of hatchery (e.g., fin clipped) versus wild salmonids were determined by observations of marked and unmarked fish along each reference site. The observations of marked fish provide a relative gauge of the extent of hatchery fish invasions in park rivers. These observations only apply to adult salmonids. Divers made frequent stops to compare and minimize duplication of counts. The sampling procedure of snorkel counts was consistent within and among years, and consistent among rivers.

Some weekly snorkel counts were missed due to high river flows that would have significantly reduced survey safety and accuracy. The Elwha River and the Dosewallips River, which are typically sampled, were unable to be sampled during the 2011 season because of high flows and unsafe conditions. Limited numbers of surveys were conducted on the rivers in the Quinault system and the South Fork Hoh River for the same reason. The high flows during the 2011 season can be attributed mainly to a late and prolonged snow melt.

Over the period of data collection (1994-2011) there were changes in how data were recorded. They include: - Observers had the option of recording river flow as moderately high in some years and not in others. - River temperature was recorded in the early years of the project as the protocol was being developed, though this effort was later dropped. - There are instances where fish measurements are recorded in inches rather than centimeters.

Data Management Data were entered into the project database following each data collection event. Database records were later verified for complete and accurate transcription by retrieving and visually comparing the data associated with each sampling event against the original forms. Once all data for the season were entered and verified, a rigorous quality review was conducted on the data set by running a set of pre-built validation queries to check for completeness, missing or out-of-range values, logical consistency, and structural integrity. Errors identified during this review were corrected where possible, and annotations related to specific issues raised by each query were stored within the project database as needed and appropriate. After data validation was complete, survey lengths were digitized from recent aerial imagery in a geographic information system (GIS) and added to the database. The data set was then certified as complete and ready for use.

The data are certified. Data certification is a benchmark in the project information management process that indicates that: 1) the data are complete for the period of record; 2) they have undergone and passed the quality assurance checks; and 3) that they are appropriately documented and in a condition for archiving, posting and distribution as appropriate. Certification is not intended to imply that the data are completely free of errors or inconsistencies which may or may not have been detected during quality assurance reviews.

Data Package Processing Locations and EventsSnorkel data were both exported as XLSX files from an Access relational database and then saved as CSV files before being read into R for processing. Some processing was done in XSLX format, including formatting date and time columns to ISO standards, rounding UTM coordinates to whole numbers and reformatting some numeric columns to match the original data format in Access.
